moves.1. d4 Nf6 2. Nf3 e6 3. c4 b6 4. Bg5: Unusual. 4.g3 and 4.a3 are the normal moves these days.
moves.4... Bb7 5. e3: White is determined to avoid having his QN pinned, but doesn't want to waste a move by playing a3.
moves.5... h6 6. Bh4 Be7: The more aggressive 6...g5 has yielded good results.
moves.7. Nc3: Now that Black has committed his bishop to e7, the time is right to develop this knight.
moves.7... c5: An important move in most variations of the Queen's Indian, but Black needs to be sure that White can't play 8.d5. Here Black can simply play 8...Nxd5.
moves.8. Bxf6:
A strange move. If White wanted to exchange bishop for knight, he should have done it on move 6.

Wang Yue (2739)-Ivanchuk,V (2779), Nice FRA 2009, continued 8.Be2 0-0 9.0-0 Nc6 10.Bg3 cxd4 11.Nxd4 d6 12.Bf3 Qd7 with a draw in 69 moves.

Gelfand,B (2733)-Leko,P (2749), Monte Carlo MNC 2007, continued 8.Bd3 cxd4 9.exd4 0-0 10.0-0 Nc6 11.Rc1 d5 12.cxd5 Nxd5 with a draw in 72 moves.
moves.8... Bxf6 9. Be2 cxd4 10. exd4 O-O 11. O: This only increases the power of the Black bishop on f6. A developing move such as Re1 is better.
moves.12... Ne5: The knight doesn't look too secure here. 12...Ne7 - tempting White to play 13.d6 -  is probably better.
moves.13. Nd4: White embarks on an ill thought out plan when he should be completing his development.
moves.14... Nxc4 15. Bxc4 Rxc4 16. d6: Losing another pawn and the game.
moves.16... a6 17. Qb3: After 17.Na3 Rc6 Black wins a second pawn.
Well seen!! Brings the game to a swift conclusion.
